p: Some studies on influenza outbreaks discussed issues related to vaccines. Of the three influenza outbreaks in a well-vaccinated population, two studies pointed out that a mismatch between the circulating strains and the vaccine strains affected this population [ 41, 45], and the other study noted an insufficient vaccine effectiveness [ 42]. Especially, the study by Burette et al. [ 41] identified that in addition to the mismatch, several defects including a vaccination rate of 0% among staff and untimely vaccination among residents led to the outbreaks. In addition, they raised the issue of the knowledge and proficiency of general practitioners in influenza diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.
